This document outlines the Arogya Sanjeevani Policy - National, a health insurance contract issued by National Insurance Company Limited.

The policy covers medically necessary hospitalization expenses for illness or injury, including room rent, ICU charges, surgeon/anesthetist fees, diagnostics, and other related expenses, up to the Sum Insured and Cumulative Bonus. It also covers specific treatments like cataract (with sub-limits), dental and plastic surgery due to disease/injury, day care treatments, and road ambulance charges. AYUSH treatments (Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy, Unani, Sidha, Homeopathy) are covered for inpatient care. Pre-hospitalization expenses for 30 days and post-hospitalization expenses for 60 days are also covered. Certain modern treatments are covered up to 50% of the Sum Insured.

Key definitions include Accident, Age, AIDS, Any One Illness, AYUSH Day Care/Hospital, Break in Policy, Cashless Facility, Congenital Anomaly, Co-payment (5% for insureds <=75 years, 15% for >75 years), Cumulative Bonus (5% increase per claim-free year, up to 50% of SI), Day Care Treatment, Dental Treatment, Diagnosis, Emergency Care, Family (spouse, parents, parents-in-law, dependent children 3 months-25 years), Grace Period (30 days), Hospital, Illness (Acute/Chronic), Injury, In-Patient Care, ICU Charges, Medical Advice/Expenses/Practitioner/Treatment, Migration, New Born Baby, Network/Non-Network Provider, Notification of Claim, OPD Treatment, Pre-Existing Disease, Policy Period, Portability, Qualified Nurse, Renewal, Room Rent, Sub-limit, Sum Insured, Surgery, and Third Party Administrator (TPA).

The policy has various waiting periods: 36 months for Pre-Existing Diseases, 30 days for any illness from policy commencement (except accidents), and 24 months for specified diseases/procedures.

Exclusions include expenses for investigation/evaluation only, rest cure/rehabilitation, obesity/weight control surgery (unless specific conditions met), change-of-gender treatments, cosmetic/plastic surgery (unless for reconstruction post-accident/burn/cancer), hazardous/adventure sports injuries, treatment due to breach of law, treatment by excluded providers (with exceptions for life-threatening accidents), drug/alcohol abuse, non-medical admissions, vitamins/tonics (unless prescribed as part of hospitalization), unproven treatments, sterility/infertility, maternity expenses (except ectopic pregnancy), war, and nuclear/chemical/biological attacks. Domiciliary hospitalization and OPD treatment are also excluded.

Claim procedures involve cashless facility through TPA (pre-authorization required) or reimbursement (documents to be submitted within 30 days for hospitalization/pre-hospitalization and 15 days for post-hospitalization). Claims are settled within 15 days (or 45 days if investigation is needed), with interest payable for delays.

General terms cover disclosure of information, conditions precedent, material change notification, record maintenance, complete discharge, notice & communication, territorial limit (India only), multiple policies, fraud (leading to forfeiture of benefits), cancellation (by company with 15 days notice for misrepresentation/fraud, no refund; by policyholder with 7 days notice, proportionate refund if no claim), territorial jurisdiction (Indian courts), and arbitration for quantum disputes.

The policy offers migration and portability benefits for continuity. Renewal is generally allowed unless the product is withdrawn or there's established fraud/misrepresentation. Premium can be paid in installments. A 30-day free look period is available at inception.

The document also includes detailed lists of expenses not covered or subsumed into room/procedure charges, and contact details for Insurance Ombudsman offices for grievance redressal.
Arogya Sanjeevani Policy - National

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?

This document outlines the Arogya Sanjeevani Policy - National, a health insurance contract issued by National Insurance Company Limited.

The policy covers medically necessary hospitalization expenses for illness or injury, up to the Sum Insured and Cumulative Bonus, subject to specific terms, exclusions, and conditions.

Key aspects of the policy include:
*   **Definitions:** Detailed explanations for terms such as Accident, Age, AIDS, AYUSH Day Care Centre, AYUSH Hospital, AYUSH Treatment, Cashless Facility, Congenital Anomaly, Co-payment, Cumulative Bonus, Day Care Treatment, Dental Treatment, Diagnosis, Emergency Care, Family, Grace Period, Hospital, Illness, Injury, In-Patient Care, Intensive Care Unit (ICU) Charges, Medical Advice, Medical Expenses, Medically Necessary Treatment, Medical Practitioner, Migration, New Born Baby, Network Provider, Non-Network Provider, Notification of Claim, Out-Patient (OPD) Treatment, Pre-Existing Disease, Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses, Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses, Policy, Policy Period, Policy Schedule, Portability, Qualified Nurse, Renewal, Room Rent, Sub-limit, Sum Insured, Surgery or Surgical Procedure, Third Party Administrator (TPA), and Waiting Period.
*   **Coverage:**
    *   **Hospitalization:** Includes Room Rent (up to 2% of SI, max Rs. 5,000/day), ICU/ICCU expenses (up to 5% of SI, max Rs. 10,000/day), Surgeon, Anesthetist, Medical Practitioner, Consultants, Specialist Fees, Anesthesia, blood, oxygen, operation theatre charges, surgical appliances, medicines, drugs, diagnostics, and diagnostic imaging modalities.
    *   **Other Expenses:** Cataract treatment (25% of SI or Rs. 40,000/eye, whichever is lower), dental/plastic surgery due to disease/injury, all day care treatments, and road ambulance (max Rs. 2,000/hospitalization).
    *   **AYUSH Treatment:** Inpatient care under Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Sidha, and Homeopathy systems up to Sum Insured.
    *   **Pre-hospitalisation:** Medical expenses for 30 days prior to hospitalization.
    *   **Post-hospitalisation:** Medical expenses for 60 days after discharge from hospital.
    *   **Modern Treatment:** Specific procedures covered up to 50% of the Sum Insured.
*   **Cumulative Bonus (CB):** Increases by 5% for each claim-free policy period (max 50% of SI), reduced at the same rate if a claim is made.
*   **Waiting Period:**
    *   Pre-Existing Diseases: 36 months of continuous coverage.
    *   First 30 days: For any illness (except accident).
    *   Specified diseases/procedures: 24 or 36 months of continuous coverage.
*   **Exclusions:** Include investigation/evaluation, rest cure/rehabilitation, obesity/weight control, change-of-gender treatments, cosmetic/plastic surgery (unless reconstructive), hazardous/adventure sports, breach of law, excluded providers, drug/alcohol abuse, non-medical admissions, vitamins/tonics (unless prescribed), refractive error, unproven treatments, sterility/infertility, maternity expenses, war, nuclear/chemical/biological attack, domiciliary hospitalization, OPD treatment, and treatment outside India.
*   **Moratorium Period:** After 60 continuous months, claims are not contestable on grounds of non-disclosure/misrepresentation, except for established fraud.
*   **Claim Procedure:** Cashless facility (via TPA with pre-authorization) and reimbursement process with specified time limits and required documents.
*   **Co-payment:** 5% for insured persons aged 75 years or less, and 15% for those aged greater than 75 years.
*   **General Terms & Conditions:** Cover disclosure of information, condition precedent to admission of liability, material change notification, record maintenance, complete discharge, notice & communication, territorial limit (India only), multiple policies, fraud, cancellation, territorial jurisdiction, arbitration, migration, portability, renewal, premium payment in installments, product withdrawal, revision of terms, and free look period.
*   **Table of Benefits:** Summarizes the policy's features, including Sum Insured (Rs. 50,000 to Rs. 10L), Policy Period (1 year), Eligibility (18-65 years for proposer, children 3 months-25 years), Grace Period (30 days), and details on various coverages and sub-limits.
*   **Annexure-A:** Provides lists of items not covered, items subsumed into room charges, items subsumed into procedure charges, and items subsumed into costs of treatment.
*   **Annexure-B:** Contains contact details for Insurance Ombudsman offices across India.
Arogya Sanjeevani Policy - National

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of these rights except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that protects individuals against arbitrary actions of the state and has been interpreted to include a wide range of rights such as the right to privacy, right to a fair trial, right to livelihood, and right to a clean environment.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above), including in matters of admission to educational institutions and reservation in services under the State.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

answers: Expenses for treatment of arthritis at home would not be covered under Domiciliary Hospitalisation Cover, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required. This is because arthritis is specifically excluded from this cover.

The prosthetic device is payable as it is a necessary part of the treatment immediately following surgery.

The lumbar belt (LUMBO SACRAL BELT) is only payable for cases involving surgery of the lumbar spine, as stated in Annexure-I, List I, Sr. No. 47, and the claim is for a hip replacement surgery.

An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unmarried and unemployed) requiring dental surgery after an accident is eligible for coverage.

**Claim Admissibility:**
*   **Eligibility:** Children above 18 years will continue to be covered along with parents up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.
*   **Dental Exclusions:** Dental treatment, dentures, or surgery of any kind is covered if necessitated due to an accident and requiring minimum 24 hours hospitalization. Treatment related to gum disease or tooth disease or damage is excluded unless related to irreversible bone disease involving the jaw which cannot be treated in any other way. Since the dental surgery is required due to an accident, it is admissible.

**Process for this specific scenario:**
1.  **Notification of Claim:**
    *   Notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
    *   For planned hospitalization, notify at least 48 hours prior to admission.
2.  **Procedure for Cashless Claims (if applicable):**
    *   Contact the TPA's toll-free number for claim intimation and assistance.
    *   Produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the Hospital Insurance-desk upon admission.
    *   Complete and send the cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
    *   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter after verification.
    *   The treatment must take place within 15 days of the pre-authorization date at a Network Provider, and details must match the actual treatment received.
    *   At discharge, verify and sign discharge papers and the final bill, and pay for non-medical and inadmissible expenses.
    *   If pre-authorization is denied, the insured may proceed with treatment and submit documents for reimbursement.
3.  **Procedure for Reimbursement of Claims:**
    *   Submit the duly completed claim form and supporting original documents to the TPA within the prescribed time limit.
    *   For hospitalisation and pre-hospitalisation expenses, documents must be submitted within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital.
    *   For post-hospitalisation expenses, documents must be submitted within 15 days from completion of post-hospitalisation treatment.

**Required Documents:**
*   Duly completed claim form
*   Photo ID and Age proof
*   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital
*   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

Expenses for Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) are restricted to 50% of the Sum Insured, as it is one of the 12 modern treatments as per IRDAI.

For ICU care, the expenses for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU are covered up to the actual expenses incurred, as specified in the Policy Schedule. The definition of a hospital in a city with a population over 1,000,000 requires at least 15 in-patient beds.

To add a newly-adopted child as a dependent, the policyholder must follow these steps:

**Process for adding a dependent:**
1.  Provide written notification to the insurer.
2.  Ensure the application for cover is accepted by the insurer.
3.  Pay the additional pro-rata premium for the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person.
4.  The insurer will issue an endorsement confirming the addition of the person as an Insured Person.
5.  Notify the insurer of any changes in membership on or before the last day of the succeeding month.

**Circumstances under which the insurer may refuse cover for the child:**
The document does not explicitly mention "adopted child" but covers "children" as dependents. For eligibility, the child must be between 91 days and 18 years old, and either or both parents must be covered concurrently (Clause V.B.3.b.iii). The 3-year-old child meets the age criteria.

Refusal of cover may occur under these circumstances:
*   The application for cover is not accepted by the insurer (Clause V.B.12.A).
*   The additional pro-rata premium is not received by the insurer (Clause V.B.12.A, V.B.5).
*   There is misrepresentation, fraud, or non-disclosure of material fact by the policyholder related to the child (Clause V.A.2, V.A.10).
*   The policyholder fails to provide any required additional information or documents requested by the underwriter for assessment (Clause V.B.13).

For a day care cataract procedure and subsequent 5 days of inpatient care in a non-network hospital due to complications, which is considered a relapse and part of the same claim as it occurred within two weeks of the initial procedure:

**Claim Notification Timelines:**
1.  **Day Care Cataract Procedure (if planned):** Notify the TPA in writing at least 48 hours prior to admission.
2.  **Subsequent 5 Days Inpatient Care (emergency hospitalization):** Notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.

The notification should include all relevant information, such as the plan of treatment and policy number.

**Claim Submission and Document Requirements (Reimbursement for Non-Network Hospital):**
Payment for treatment in a non-network hospital must be made up-front by the insured. The necessary documents must be submitted to the TPA within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital.

*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital
*   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital

*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries (e.g., lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery)
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months

The newborn's treatment expenses are eligible for a claim.

*   **Newborn Cover Terms:** A "New Born Baby" is defined as a baby born during the policy period and aged up to 90 days. New Born Babies are accepted for cover from birth if the mother is covered and maternity cover is opted. The policy's "Other Special Condition Details" (SL. No. 1) explicitly state that the "Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured".
*   **Definitions and Coverage:** "In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover" includes "Reasonable and Customary Charges" for medically necessary treatment, which covers "Charges for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU".
*   **Exclusions:** While "Maternity (Code-Excl18)" generally excludes medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections) except for ectopic pregnancy, this is superseded by the "Other Special Condition Details" (SL. No. 1) which specifically state "Maternity Benefit for Normal & C-Section Covered Limited to INR 50,000 for Normal and INR 50,000 for c-section" and "Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured".

No, the provided documents are likely not sufficient.

A prescription from a general practitioner is acceptable as a general practitioner is a "Medical Practitioner" as defined by the policy.

However, a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist is likely not sufficient to meet the policy's requirements for inpatient psychiatric treatment claims. The policy defines a "Medical Practitioner" as a person holding a valid registration from the Medical Council of any State or Medical Council of India or Council for Indian Medicine or for Homeopathy, and entitled to practice medicine within their jurisdiction. A "Clinical Psychologist" is defined as a "Mental Healthcare Professional" but is not included in the definition of a "Medical Practitioner" who can provide medical advice for treatment leading to hospitalization.

Claim document rules for inpatient hospitalization and critical illness (which includes mental illnesses for documentation purposes) require an "Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis" and a "Medical certificate confirming the diagnosis of Critical Illness". These certifications are expected from a "Medical Practitioner" as defined by the policy, which typically refers to a medical doctor (e.g., a psychiatrist for mental health conditions), not a Clinical Psychologist.

ECG electrodes and gloves are admissible for reimbursement under the following constraints:

*   **ECG Electrodes:** Up to 5 electrodes are required for every case visiting OT or ICU. For longer stays in ICU, a change may be required, and at least one set every second day is payable.
*   **Gloves:** Sterilized gloves are payable, while unsterilized gloves are not payable.

Pre-hospitalization expenses incurred 18 days before admission can be claimed as they fall within the policy's 30-day limit for Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover. These expenses are covered as Actual Expenses Incurred, provided they are for the same condition for which hospitalization was required and the in-patient hospitalization claim is admissible.

Post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses incurred 20 days after discharge can also be claimed. These expenses fall within the policy's 60-day limit for Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover and are covered as Actual Expenses Incurred, provided they are for the same condition for which hospitalization was required and the in-patient hospitalization claim is admissible.

A dependent child's coverage continues up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent. When a dependent insured person ceases to be a dependent, their coverage is terminated, unless otherwise agreed specifically for continuation until the end of the policy period. Therefore, if a dependent child turns 27, their coverage terminates upon reaching that age.

Associated expenses are reimbursed based on the Proportionate Clause, as per Note 1 of Clause III.A.1.A. If the insured is admitted to a room at rates exceeding the limits mentioned in the Policy Schedule/Certificate of Insurance, the reimbursement of all associated medical expenses incurred at the hospital is effected in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent. This proportionate deduction does not apply to hospitals where differential billing is not followed or where differential billing is not adopted based on the room category.

questions: If an insured person takes treatment for arthritis at home because no hospital beds are available, under what circumstances would these expenses NOT be covered, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required?

An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unemployed and unmarried) requires dental surgery after an accident. What is the claim admissibility, considering both eligibility and dental exclusions, and what is the process for this specific scenario?

If an insured undergoes Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) during brain surgery, and also needs ICU care in a city over 1 million population, how are the respective expenses limited according to modern treatments, critical care definition, and policy schedule?

What is the claim eligibility for the newborn's treatment expenses, referencing definitions, exclusions, and newborn cover terms?

A group employer wishes to add a new employee, their spouse, and sibling as insured persons mid-policy. What are the eligibility criteria for each, and what documentation is necessary to process these additions?
Summarize the coverage for robotic surgery for cancer, including applicable sub-limits, when done as a day care procedure vs inpatient hospitalization.

If an accident necessitates air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, what steps must be followed for both pre-authorization and claims assessment? Discuss mandatory requirements and documentation.

Explain how the policy treats waiting periods for a specific illness (e.g., knee replacement due to osteoarthritis) if an insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer but recently ported to this policy.

If a doctor prescribes an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment, will the expense be covered? Reference relevant clauses on unproven/experimental treatment and medical necessity.
A member of a non-employer group policy dies during the policy period. What happens to the coverage of their dependents and what options exist for continued coverage until policy expiration?

For claims involving implanted devices (e.g., cardiac stents), what is the requirement for supporting documentation, and how might the claim be affected if only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided?

A spouse suffers a serious accident and is incapacitated, requiring prolonged home nursing after discharge. Under what circumstances would these home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement, and what documentation is needed?

In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, what is the procedure for claim settlement, coordination, and required documentation?

List scenarios where prostheses or medical appliances are NOT covered, even if associated with hospitalization. Use definitions and exclusions for your justification.

answers: Expenses for treatment of arthritis at home would not be covered under Domiciliary Hospitalisation Cover, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required. This is because arthritis is specifically excluded from this cover.

The prosthetic device is payable as it is a necessary part of the treatment immediately following surgery.

The walker and lumbar belt are not payable. The walker is listed as "Not Payable" in Annexure-I, List I, Sr. No. 34. The lumbar belt (LUMBO SACRAL BELT) is only payable for cases involving surgery of the lumbar spine, as stated in Annexure-I, List I, Sr. No. 47, and the claim is for a hip replacement surgery.

An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unmarried and unemployed) requiring dental surgery after an accident is eligible for coverage.

**Claim Admissibility:**
*   **Eligibility:** Children above 18 years will continue to be covered along with parents up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.
*   **Dental Exclusions:** Dental treatment, dentures, or surgery of any kind is covered if necessitated due to an accident and requiring minimum 24 hours hospitalization. Treatment related to gum disease or tooth disease or damage is excluded unless related to irreversible bone disease involving the jaw which cannot be treated in any other way. Since the dental surgery is required due to an accident, it is admissible.

**Process for this specific scenario:**
1.  **Notification of Claim:**
    *   Notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
    *   For planned hospitalization, notify at least 48 hours prior to admission.
2.  **Procedure for Cashless Claims (if applicable):**
    *   Contact the TPA's toll-free number for claim intimation and assistance.
    *   Produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the Hospital Insurance-desk upon admission.
    *   Complete and send the cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
    *   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter after verification.
    *   The treatment must take place within 15 days of the pre-authorization date at a Network Provider, and details must match the actual treatment received.
    *   At discharge, verify and sign discharge papers and the final bill, and pay for non-medical and inadmissible expenses.
    *   If pre-authorization is denied, the insured may proceed with treatment and submit documents for reimbursement.
3.  **Procedure for Reimbursement of Claims:**
    *   Submit the duly completed claim form and supporting original documents to the TPA within the prescribed time limit.
    *   For hospitalisation and pre-hospitalisation expenses, documents must be submitted within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital.
    *   For post-hospitalisation expenses, documents must be submitted within 15 days from completion of post-hospitalisation treatment.

**Required Documents:**
*   Duly completed claim form
*   Photo ID and Age proof
*   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital
*   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

Expenses for Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) are restricted to 50% of the Sum Insured, as it is one of the 12 modern treatments as per IRDAI.

For ICU care, the expenses for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU are covered up to the actual expenses incurred, as specified in the Policy Schedule. The definition of a hospital in a city with a population over 1,000,000 requires at least 15 in-patient beds.

To add a newly-adopted child as a dependent, the policyholder must follow these steps:

**Process for adding a dependent:**
1.  Provide written notification to the insurer.
2.  Ensure the application for cover is accepted by the insurer.
3.  Pay the additional pro-rata premium for the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person.
4.  The insurer will issue an endorsement confirming the addition of the person as an Insured Person.
5.  Notify the insurer of any changes in membership on or before the last day of the succeeding month.

**Circumstances under which the insurer may refuse cover for the child:**
The document does not explicitly mention "adopted child" but covers "children" as dependents. For eligibility, the child must be between 91 days and 18 years old, and either or both parents must be covered concurrently (Clause V.B.3.b.iii). The 3-year-old child meets the age criteria.

Refusal of cover may occur under these circumstances:
*   The application for cover is not accepted by the insurer (Clause V.B.12.A).
*   The additional pro-rata premium is not received by the insurer (Clause V.B.12.A, V.B.5).
*   There is misrepresentation, fraud, or non-disclosure of material fact by the policyholder related to the child (Clause V.A.2, V.A.10).
*   The policyholder fails to provide any required additional information or documents requested by the underwriter for assessment (Clause V.B.13).

Relevant clauses:
*   **Unproven/Experimental Treatment (Section II.A.43, Page 19)**: This refers to treatment, including drug experimental therapy, which is not based on established medical practice in India, is treatment experimental or unproven.
*   **Medically Necessary Treatment (Section II.A.27, Page 19)**: This requires that the treatment must conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India.
*   **Unproven Treatments (Code-Excl16) (Section IV.B.16, Page 25)**: Expenses related to any unproven treatment, services, and supplies for or in connection with any treatment are excluded. Unproven treatments are those that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness.

answers: Expenses for treatment of arthritis at home would not be covered under Domiciliary Hospitalisation Cover, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required. This is because arthritis is specifically excluded from this cover.

The prosthetic device is payable as it is a necessary part of the treatment immediately following surgery.

The walker and lumbar belt are not payable. The walker is listed as "Not Payable" in Annexure-I, List I, Sr. No. 34. The lumbar belt (LUMBO SACRAL BELT) is only payable for cases involving surgery of the lumbar spine, as stated in Annexure-I, List I, Sr. No. 47, and the claim is for a hip replacement surgery.

An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unmarried and unemployed) requiring dental surgery after an accident is eligible for coverage.

**Claim Admissibility:**
*   **Eligibility:** Children above 18 years will continue to be covered along with parents up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.
*   **Dental Exclusions:** Dental treatment, dentures, or surgery of any kind is covered if necessitated due to an accident and requiring minimum 24 hours hospitalization. Treatment related to gum disease or tooth disease or damage is excluded unless related to irreversible bone disease involving the jaw which cannot be treated in any other way. Since the dental surgery is required due to an accident, it is admissible.

**Process for this specific scenario:**
1.  **Notification of Claim:**
    *   Notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
    *   For planned hospitalization, notify at least 48 hours prior to admission.
2.  **Procedure for Cashless Claims (if applicable):**
    *   Contact the TPA's toll-free number for claim intimation and assistance.
    *   Produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the Hospital Insurance-desk upon admission.
    *   Complete and send the cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
    *   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter after verification.
    *   The treatment must take place within 15 days of the pre-authorization date at a Network Provider, and details must match the actual treatment received.
    *   At discharge, verify and sign discharge papers and the final bill, and pay for non-medical and inadmissible expenses.
    *   If pre-authorization is denied, the insured may proceed with treatment and submit documents for reimbursement.
3.  **Procedure for Reimbursement of Claims:**
    *   Submit the duly completed claim form and supporting original documents to the TPA within the prescribed time limit.
    *   For hospitalisation and pre-hospitalisation expenses, documents must be submitted within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital.
    *   For post-hospitalisation expenses, documents must be submitted within 15 days from completion of post-hospitalisation treatment.

**Required Documents:**
*   Duly completed claim form
*   Photo ID and Age proof
*   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital
*   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

For ICU care, the expenses for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU are covered up to the actual expenses incurred, as specified in the Policy Schedule. The definition of a hospital in a city with a population over 1,000,000 requires at least 15 in-patient beds.

To add a newly-adopted child as a dependent, the policyholder must follow these steps:

**Process for adding a dependent:**
1.  Provide written notification to the insurer.
2.  Ensure the application for cover is accepted by the insurer.
3.  Pay the additional pro-rata premium for the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person.
4.  The insurer will issue an endorsement confirming the addition of the person as an Insured Person.
5.  Notify the insurer of any changes in membership on or before the last day of the succeeding month.

**Circumstances under which the insurer may refuse cover for the child:**
The document does not explicitly mention "adopted child" but covers "children" as dependents. For eligibility, the child must be between 91 days and 18 years old, and either or both parents must be covered concurrently (Clause V.B.3.b.iii). The 3-year-old child meets the age criteria.

Refusal of cover may occur under these circumstances:
*   The application for cover is not accepted by the insurer (Clause V.B.12.A).
*   The additional pro-rata premium is not received by the insurer (Clause V.B.12.A, V.B.5).
*   There is misrepresentation, fraud, or non-disclosure of material fact by the policyholder related to the child (Clause V.A.2, V.A.10).
*   The policyholder fails to provide any required additional information or documents requested by the underwriter for assessment (Clause V.B.13).

The newborn's treatment expenses are eligible for a claim.

*   **Newborn Cover Terms:** A "New Born Baby" is defined as a baby born during the policy period and aged up to 90 days. New Born Babies are accepted for cover from birth if the mother is covered and maternity cover is opted. The policy's "Other Special Condition Details" (SL. No. 1) explicitly state that the "Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured".
*   **Definitions and Coverage:** "In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover" includes "Reasonable and Customary Charges" for medically necessary treatment, which covers "Charges for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU".
*   **Exclusions:** While "Maternity (Code-Excl18)" generally excludes medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections) except for ectopic pregnancy, this is superseded by the "Other Special Condition Details" (SL. No. 1) which specifically state "Maternity Benefit for Normal & C-Section Covered Limited to INR 50,000 for Normal and INR 50,000 for c-section" and "Baby Covered from Day 1 within Family Sum Insured".

A prescription from a general practitioner is acceptable as a general practitioner is a "Medical Practitioner" as defined by the policy.

However, a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist is likely not sufficient to meet the policy's requirements for inpatient psychiatric treatment claims. The policy defines a "Medical Practitioner" as a person holding a valid registration from the Medical Council of any State or Medical Council of India or Council for Indian Medicine or for Homeopathy, and entitled to practice medicine within their jurisdiction. A "Clinical Psychologist" is defined as a "Mental Healthcare Professional" but is not included in the definition of a "Medical Practitioner" who can provide medical advice for treatment leading to hospitalization.

Claim document rules for inpatient hospitalization and critical illness (which includes mental illnesses for documentation purposes) require an "Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis" and a "Medical certificate confirming the diagnosis of Critical Illness". These certifications are expected from a "Medical Practitioner" as defined by the policy, which typically refers to a medical doctor (e.g., a psychiatrist for mental health conditions), not a Clinical Psychologist.

ECG electrodes and gloves are admissible for reimbursement under the following constraints:

*   **ECG Electrodes:** Up to 5 electrodes are required for every case visiting OT or ICU. For longer stays in ICU, a change may be required, and at least one set every second day is payable.
*   **Gloves:** Sterilized gloves are payable, while unsterilized gloves are not payable.

Pre-hospitalization expenses incurred 18 days before admission can be claimed as they fall within the policy's 30-day limit for Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover. These expenses are covered as Actual Expenses Incurred, provided they are for the same condition for which hospitalization was required and the in-patient hospitalization claim is admissible.

Post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses incurred 20 days after discharge can also be claimed. These expenses fall within the policy's 60-day limit for Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover and are covered as Actual Expenses Incurred, provided they are for the same condition for which hospitalization was required and the in-patient hospitalization claim is admissible.

A dependent child's coverage continues up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent. When a dependent insured person ceases to be a dependent, their coverage is terminated, unless otherwise agreed specifically for continuation until the end of the policy period. Therefore, if a dependent child turns 27, their coverage terminates upon reaching that age.

Associated expenses are reimbursed based on the Proportionate Clause, as per Note 1 of Clause III.A.1.A. If the insured is admitted to a room at rates exceeding the limits mentioned in the Policy Schedule/Certificate of Insurance, the reimbursement of all associated medical expenses incurred at the hospital is effected in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent. This proportionate deduction does not apply to hospitals where differential billing is not followed or where differential billing is not adopted based on the room category.

Yes, the claim is eligible under Day Care Treatment.

Day Care Treatment means medical treatment and/or surgical procedure which is:
i. undertaken under General or Local Anesthesia in a hospital/day care centre in less than 24 hours because of technological advancement, and
ii. which would have otherwise required a hospitalisation of more than 24 hours. Treatment normally taken on an out-patient basis is not included in the scope of this definition.

When the insured is hospitalized in a town with a population of less than 1,000,000, the hospital must have at least 10 in-patient beds to qualify under this policy. In metropolitan areas, or "all other places," the hospital must have at least 15 in-patient beds.

Additionally, for a hospital to qualify, it must:
*   Have qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock.
*   Have qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock.
*   Have a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out.
*   Maintain daily records of patients and make them accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.

**Eligibility Criteria for Additions Mid-Policy:**

*   **New Employee:** Must be a newly appointed employee of the policyholder.
*   **Spouse:** Must be the newly wedded spouse of the employee.
*   **Sibling:** Must be the employee

If the insured person has been continuously covered without any break under a health insurance policy with an Indian General/Health Insurer, the waiting period for specific illnesses, such as knee replacement due to osteoarthritis, will be reduced to the extent of prior coverage, as per IRDAI guidelines on portability.

No, the expense for an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment will not be covered if it falls under the definition of "Unproven/Experimental Treatment" or does not conform to "professional standards widely accepted in India."

Relevant clauses:
*   **Unproven/Experimental Treatment (Section II.A.43, Page 19)**: This refers to treatment, including drug experimental therapy, which is not based on established medical practice in India, is treatment experimental or unproven.
*   **Medically Necessary Treatment (Section II.A.27, Page 19)**: This requires that the treatment must conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India.
*   **Unproven Treatments (Code-Excl16) (Section IV.B.16, Page 25)**: Expenses related to any unproven treatment, services, and supplies for or in connection with any treatment are excluded. Unproven treatments are those that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness.

For claims involving implanted devices such as cardiac stents, the required supporting documentation includes the original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during surgeries.

If only a generic invoice without an implant sticker is provided, it will be considered a deficiency in the necessary claim documents. The Insured Person/Network Provider will be intimated about this deficiency. If the deficiency is not met or is only partially met within 10 working days of the first intimation, the company may, at its sole discretion, deduct the amount of the claim for which the deficiency is intimated and settle the remaining claim if it is otherwise valid under the Policy.

Home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement under the following circumstances:

*   It provides expert nursing services immediately after Hospital Treatment.
*   It is required for as long as medically necessary.
*   The Specialist who treated the patient must have recommended these services.

In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the primary Insurer will seek details of other available policies of the policyholder and coordinate with other Insurers to ensure settlement of the balance amount, as per the policy conditions, provided a written request for the same has been submitted by the Insured Person.

According to the policy's **Standard Permanent Exclusions**, specifically **4. Investigation & Evaluation (Code-Excl04)**:
*   Expenses related to any admission primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes only are excluded.
*   Any diagnostic expenses which are not related or incidental to the current diagnosis and treatment are excluded.

Furthermore, the definitions of **17. Hospitalisation** and **20. Inpatient Care** imply that admission and stay in a hospital are for "treatment" of an illness or injury. If no treatment was decided upon after evaluation, the expenses fall under the exclusion for admissions primarily for diagnostics and evaluation.
